content:
Both can occur in mathlib if f is a variable. Do we have a preference between them?

@loogle iSup
I think we should generally avoid the former, for the simple reason "we might as well use the available notation"
well one of them is iSup f and the other one is iSup fun i => f i
Well, if you need another reason, I believe most of the iSup/iInf API is written using the notation.
Any exceptions within the ordinal/cardinal part of the library (which I think is what spawned this thread) are either historical accident or my fault.

Violeta Hernández said:

Well, if you need another reason, I believe most of the iSup/iInf API is written using the notation.

well if you have a function which is not a free variable might as well use the notation but
what about functions which are free variables

Aaron Liu said:

well one of them is iSup f and the other one is iSup fun i => f i

Are the both only different in the format? It seems that rw knows f = fun i => f i and does rewrite appropriately for both f and fun i => f i. If so, I agree we should prefer ⨆ i, f i.

Indeed having iSup f can sometimes work better, but I think unless the eta expanded form iSup fun i => f i is explicitly causing problems, we should use the notation. And if it is causing problems, we should strive to make our tactics better to avoid the problems :)
